article: I was in the queue for the supermarket checkout earlier today.All of the checkouts were _ , and the woman behind me was not happy! Every word that came from her mouth was a(n) _ ! She wasn't happy with the number of checkouts _ ; she wasn't happy with the amount of shopping some people had in their baskets; she wasn't happy because this supermarket didn't have a stand where she _ scan her own shopping. I listened to her _ looking around as I loaded my stuff onto the conveyor belt .I didn't want _ to do with that kind of attitude, and if ever I'd felt like letting someone go _ of me, it wouldn't be such a woman! But then I _ back.Standing beside the woman was a five-year-old girl, _ her granddaughter.The girl's part of the shopping _ of some comic books. I couldn't _ it.I pushed my shopping back to the end of the conveyor belt, _ a space."After you," I said to the woman and the girl, and _ them to a big _ .The woman was delighted, and even _ to complain ---- until she was walking away. So, _ bother having helped? It was because that little girl was probably taking in her granny's complaint like a sponge .She was learning how to deal with situations like that by listening to her granny.I'd seen that I could interrupt that complaining, and put a smile and some _ into the middle of it. We can all complain; we can all react _ , but it doesn't have to be like that.And, even if only for a few _ , I wanted to leave that little soul with just a glimpse of another way.
